Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the High School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Use transition words to improve the flow of your writing.

Human aging is a complex process that happens to all of us over time. It's like when a plant grows from a tiny seed into a big, strong tree. As we get older, our bodies change in many ways. Our skin starts to wrinkle, our hair turns gray, and our bones can become fragile. Inside our bodies, cells that repair damage start to work slower. Our organs, like our heart and brain, may not function as well as they used to. Scientists aren't sure exactly why we age, but they think it might be because our cells stop dividing and multiplying as efficiently as they did when we were younger. This can make it harder for our bodies to fight off diseases and injuries. It's important to remember that while aging is a natural part of life, there are things we can do to stay healthy and active as we get older, like eating well, exercising regularly, and getting enough sleep.

These changes are a normal part of life, but scientists are still studying them to better understand how to keep us healthy as we age.

Human aging is the gradual physical and mental changes that occur in people over time. It starts from the moment we are born and continues throughout our lives. Some changes, like growing taller or learning new skills, are positive. However, as we get older, many changes become less desirable. Our skin wrinkles, our hair turns gray, and our muscles weaken. Our brains may not function as quickly or as well as they used to. This is because our cells and tissues wear out over time. Some cells even stop working completely. Scientists are still studying why this happens, but they think it might be because our DNA, the genetic material inside our cells, has errors that build up over time. These errors can cause our cells to stop working properly or even die. This process is called cellular aging. It's a natural part of life, but it's also the reason why we eventually become too old to live independently.

Human aging is a natural process that happens to everyone as they grow older. It's like the way a plant changes from a tiny seed into a big, strong tree over time. As people age, their bodies and minds change in many ways. For example, their skin might get wrinkles, their hair could turn gray or fall out, and they might not see or hear as well as they used to. Also, their muscles can become weaker, and they might not be able to move around as easily as before. On the inside, their organs, like the heart and lungs, may not work as efficiently. But don't worry, these changes happen gradually and at different rates for each person. Even though aging is a part of life, it's important to take care of our health to slow down these changes and live longer, healthier lives.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the High School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. You may include 2-4 specific examples of how humans age.

Human aging is a natural process that happens to everyone as we get older. It's like a slow change in our body and mind over time. As we age, our body becomes more fragile and doesn't work as well as it used to. For example, our bones can become weaker and break more easily, a condition known as osteoporosis. Our skin also changes, becoming thinner and losing its elasticity, which can cause wrinkles. Our senses, like sight and hearing, may not be as sharp as they once were. For instance, we might need glasses to read or hear conversations better. Our brain also ages, which can affect our memory and how quickly we can learn new things. But even though these changes happen, it's important to remember that aging is a normal part of life and we can still enjoy many activities and experiences as we get older.
